Class PrioQueue<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.AbstractCollection<E>
      • java.util.AbstractSet<E>
        • java.util.TreeSet<T>
          • PrioQueue<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of objects in the priority queue.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Iterable<T>, java.util.Collection<T>, java.util.NavigableSet<T>, java.util.Set<T>, java.util.SortedSet<T>

    public class PrioQueue<T>
extends java.util.TreeSet<T>
    My implementation of a fixed size priority queue. It is based on the TreeSet of JAVA. However because TreeSet does not use equals to remove certain objects, we use an auxiliary HashSet with all the elements that the TreeSet contains. Whenever we need to remove an object we first remove it from the HashSet and then put all of its objects in the TreeSet, thus maintaining the correct order of the objects.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

        The add method. Overrides the add method of TreeSet. Adds the object to the hash set and to the tree set. Checks if capacity has been reached and removes the last element if so.

      • remove

        public boolean remove(java.lang.Object o)
        The remove method. Overrides the remove method of TreeSet. Removes the certain object from the HashSet first, clears the TreeSet and reconstructs it by adding all of the elements of the HashSet.
        Specified by:
        remove in interface java.util.Collection<T>

      • contains

        public boolean contains(java.lang.Object o)
        The contains method. Overrides the contains method of TreeSet. Because the super class is based on comparing objects with compareTo and not equals, the contains method of the HashSet is used instead.
        Specified by:
        contains in interface java.util.Collection<T>
        Specified by:

        Returns:
        true iff the object is in the queue.
